section.title: What is it?
section.para: react-xml-transformer is a XML transformer tool, analog to XSLT. We aim to provide a powerful environment to enable XML rendering in real time.

You have to be aware that it is probably slower that its the competing SaxonJS or built-in, XSLTProcessor, but they have one big drawback: they're not able to render in realtime (or, maybe more precisely, they are not able to re-render parts of a document).
section.question: Glad you asked. When you try first to render XML, you may try to iterate on the DOM tree and choose the correct component to apply at the right time. But you soon realize that, as the codebase grows, it truely becomes a mess. And don't even try to think about mutating nodes around.

As XSLT does, we rely on the concept of template in order to achieve our needs. Templates are just React components, that are registered in a global context, which allows to perform requests based on XPath in order to determine the correct template for a node.

section.para: Let's assume your document.xml looks so

and, assuming your XML is located in document.xml you are now ready to start rocking ! If not, there are various ways to import a XML document in a JavaScript file. Just be aware that we require a valid DOM to work, but DOMParser lets you achieve that easily.

So let's get started with our first template! First, I have the habit to create an EntryPoint.ts to match the XMLDocument, that just applied the right template for the root element. Once again, we have to import our context.

Notice how, at the end, we call ctx.register in order to let the other components that there is this new template available. This register function takes an object as second parameter, which either take a path or a name to register the template. Templates registered by name can later be called by Transformer.CallTemplate. There are two other options available: mode, which allows to process the same node in several different ways depending on the context, and priority, which determines which template will be called if more than one matches the current node.

But you should be pretty disappointed, because if you load this page, you will witness an error No stylesheet displayed in your browser. That's because we need to import each of our templates in our App.tsx:

Let's then write a transformer for our root element ! Just like you would do with a standard React app, you just have to provide a render method, but you just have to replace your {this.props.children} by a <Transformer.ApplyTemplates {...this.ctx}/> !
Now go ahead and implement <head> and <content>, that should be easy!
